unit: Unit 7 | Inference for Quantitative Data: Means
title: TV Station Standard Deviation
question_text:
A television programmer at a local news station surveyed the last $30\text{ weekday nights}$ and recorded the number of viewers on the $10$ p.m. news.
Last year, approximately $475{,}000\text{ people}$ viewed the weekday evening news per night based off data from the entire year.
This year, $30$ randomly sampled weekday nights found an average $495{,}000\text{ people per night}$ watching the weekday evening news.
If this increase is significant at the $1\%$ level, what is the standard deviation of the sample?
solution:
Use the equation below, where $n = 30$, $x = 495,000$, and $\mu = 475,000$, then look up in the $T$-distribution table to find $29$ degrees of freedom ($n-1$) meets $1\%$ upper tail probability at $t = 2.462$.

$$t=\dfrac { \bar { X } -\mu }{ s/\sqrt { n } } $$

Solve to find $s = 44{,}494$.

If $s = 44{,}494$, then the $p$-value will be exactly $1\%$. To be significant at the $1\%$ level, the $p$-value must be lower than $1\%$. Lower variability gives stronger evidence; therefore, less variability is needed, so the standard deviation must be less than $44{,}494$.

Thus, the correct answer is Choice 'C'.
